data.title: Don't create a desktop shortcut when building
data.body: Remove the `create-shortcut` task (reasoning is below).

data.title: Scrollbar is ugly when first start/open
data.body:
When I open atom, and yes, it automatically open the last file I edited. But the problem is scroll bar is ugly (like standard scrollbar in google chrome). I must change to another tab and back to change the scrollbar.
I'm using ubuntu 14.04 (64bit) using atom 1.3.0-beta0 when i saw this error.

data.title: Suggest [ci skip] in documentation-only commits
data.body:
Helps get builds that actually change code started faster.  For example, I'm waiting on Travis to run my Electron PR, and right now it's waiting on 3 documentation-only PRs before it.

If this gets merged I'll also propose the same to atom/electron, since that seems to attract more documentation PRs :).

data.title: Missing icon on Ubuntu
data.body: I just installed atom on my ubuntu 14.04 LTS (64bit) using atom version 1.3.0-beta3 and I found the atom's icon is missing from unity dash. I only see the gear icon.

data.title: Build fails on BSD: gyp error KeyError: 'deps/breakpad/breakpad.gyp:dump_syms#target'
data.body:
Here is the command I used:

```
git clone https://github.com/atom/atom &&
cd atom &&
CC=gcc48 CXX=g++48 script/build
```

Failure log:

```
Installing build modules...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/gyp_main.py", line 18, in <module>
    sys.exit(gyp.script_main())
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/__init__.py", line 533, in script_main
    return main(sys.argv[1:])
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/__init__.py", line 526, in main
    return gyp_main(args)
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/__init__.py", line 502, in gyp_main
    params, options.check, options.circular_check)
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/__init__.py", line 129, in Load
    params['parallel'], params['root_targets'])
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/input.py", line 2756, in Load
    RemoveLinkDependenciesFromNoneTargets(targets)
  File "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/gyp/pylib/gyp/input.py", line 1501, in RemoveLinkDependenciesFromNoneTargets
    if targets[t].get('variables', {}).get('link_dependency', 0):
KeyError: 'deps/breakpad/breakpad.gyp:dump_syms#target'
gyp ERR! configure error 
```

While this is probably the node-gyp bug, it prevents for me from even seeing how atom works.

Do you see the same problem?
Maybe you can get rid of, or change some dependencies to make the build possible?
Maybe you can include npm-shrinkwrap.json?

Other nodejs-based projects work fine on FreeBSD

FreeBSD-10.2
npm-2.14.7_1
node-4.2.1

data.title: Fix removeListener calls
data.body: These are throwing exceptions when we destroy the global environment. We're getting away with it because we've already serialized state, but it's still not good.

data.title: Load packages before deserializing workspace
data.body:
Fixes #9600

This ensures that package-defined deserializers work. Tried to test it, but our global environment is still a pretty tangled mess and the tests ended up feeling like they had negative value. We really need to refactor at this layer.

data.title: Using atom as a background process fails sometimes on Mac
data.body:
We use atom as a background process. It has started to fail on a Mac since version `1.2`. Refs https://github.com/TypeStrong/atom-typescript/issues/728

**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Install Atom-typescript
2. Open a TypeScript file
3. Wait 3-6 minutes

**Expected behavior:**

The background worker should continue to work

**Observed behavior:**

If fails with error : 

``` ts
/Users/tomi/.atom/packages/atom-typescript/dist/worker/lib/workerLib.js:180 CHILD ERR STDERR: Atom Helper(63023,0x7fff74876000) malloc: *** error for object 0x7f923840ce20: pointer being freed was not allocated
```

**Screenshots and GIFs**

In dev console: 

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/376203/11227621/e7faab62-8d3b-11e5-89ba-c59d4e732bc0.png)

**Atom version:** 1.2
**OS and version:** Mac OSX 

**Installed packages:**

atom-typescript, linter

**Additional information:**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: Only happens if you use the package
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: Yes
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: Yes
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: Yes

data.title: new window on drag n drop
data.body:
when i try to drag n drop file to atom, new window creates instead of new tab. atom 1.3.0-beta3.
i used stable release about few weeks ago, all worked fine

data.title: pane:close-other-items with keybinding inserts an unexpected `„` character
data.body:
When using key bindings to trigger pane:close-other-items and there exist unsaved pane items, a `„` character is dropped on the cursors position once you close the save dialog box.

**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Open a saved file
2. Open a new file and throw some text in it
3. Go back to the first file
4. Use keybindings to close other tabs (`cmd-k alt-cmd-w` on darwin [by default](https://github.com/atom/atom/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=close-other-items))

**Expected behavior:**

All other tabs close and I carry on with my day

**Observed behavior:**

All other tabs close and a `„` character appears where my cursor is in the active tab

**Screenshots and GIFs**

![gif](http://i.imgur.com/MjODFOL.gif)

**Atom version:** 1.2.0
**OS and version:** OS X Yosemite 10.10.5

**Installed packages:**

Don't think any I have installed are relevant to the issue.

**Additional information:**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: Yes
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: No
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: Yes
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: Yes
- **Problem does not happen if you use the command palette instead of the key binding.**

data.title: Custom action for "Cmd-1" key
data.body:
Is it possible to override **cmd-1** key? Just wanted to assign "cmd-1" combination as it is by default in intellij idea/webstorm.
Trying to do like this in _keymap.cson_:

``` cson
'body':
 'cmd-1': 'tree-view:toggle'
```

but it still behaves the same as before overriding - opens first tab

data.title: Find/replace with multiple root folders does not exclude ignored files
data.body:
When doing a find/replace with a single folder open, the files ignored via `.gitignore` are excluded from the search results. (as expected)

However, when multiple root folders are in use, the previous exclusion doesn't apply and it will search every file for all the root folders. (not respecting the `.gitignore` anymore)

I'm not sure if this is related directly to #5728 or not, as I didn't see this issue mentioned there.

data.title: Update language-javascript to v0.101.0
data.body:
v0.101.0 adds proper highlighting to methods and properties.

Requires core spec changes.

data.title: Only remove node_modules on ci if changed
data.body:
_This is just a spike, the hash probably needs more stuff in it (node version, etc), just curious how it will interact with Travis_

Just opening this PR to kick off a couple Travis builds as it's the simplest way to test this change. Basically, are now using their container infrastructure which allows caching, but `script/cibuild` manually removes `node_modules` before running anyway. This just writes a sha into node_modules based on package.json and process.platform that prevents us from wiping it out of the build succeeds & the deps didn't change.

data.title: Smart tabs support (tab indent, space alignment) can be improved
data.body:
Hi there,

To be clear: smart tabs == tabs for indenting, spaces for alignment.

My settings: `softTabs: false, tabLength: 4`

So I like to use aforementioned 'smart tabs', but Atom's support is lacking in this regard.
What I do is, e.g. when aligning variables, press space 4 times (4 because, in this example, `let` or `var` is 3 characters long + a space).
At the same time, although I'm using hard tabs, Atom treats the 4 spaces as one _soft_ tab / 'indent position', meaning e.g. I can jump over it pressing left or right once (I can confirm they **are** spaces actually when inspecting _invisibles_). When having an other amount of alignment spaces, Atom will always interpret soft tabs in alignment with the `tabLength` I'm using (e.g. 9 spaces will result, in this case, to 2 soft tabs + 1 space).

Now, after pressing enter after the first line I aligned with spaces (and is hard-tabbed indented), I'd expect the editor to start/indent + align the next line the same way (e.g. Sublime Text does this well). Atom however transforms every _tabLength_ amount of spaces to a hard tab.

Related to this it would be cool/nifty if a tab pressed inside/before/after alignment spaces would actually insert spaces instead of a hard tab (also because I can't imagine in what situation such would be desirable - so it helps in preventing the unintentional..)

Cheers! :hibiscus:

data.title: Problem With Horizontal Scroll in Specific Condition
data.body:
I have created a file to replicate this problem here:
https://gist.github.com/mssio/2e559b6d53de7a2e2438

Before you copy the content of the files in Atom please make sure that the width of your atom window is not super wide (can't display more than 150 chars) and the height of your atom window is not super tall (can't display more than 60 lines). Also make sure that the atom configuration on soft wrap is turned off.

After you copy the file you can see on line 1, everything is normal, you can use horizontal scroll and continue typing on line 1 and automatically scrolled to follow the cursor. But let's try to see the line 105, in that line we can't do a horizontal scroll and if I type on that line, the window will not follow the cursor.

This is really annoying problem because a lot of my code have a format like this and when I am in the middle / bottom, I will not be able to edit the code using Atom. I have to switch to another text editor.

I hope this is not a duplicate issue, please just close it if it is a duplicate. And I am sorry for my bad English.

data.title: bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor counts tabs as spaces
data.body:
I tried to call editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor(".string") to get range of currently selected string. Then I tried to get that string by calling editor.getTextInBufferRange(range). It works as expected and I get entire string if line is indented with spaces.

If line is indented with tabs, returned string starts several characters to the right, it is the right length (or cropped if there are no more characters). bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor seems to be counting single tab as multiple characters (based on its width), while getTextInBufferRange counts tab as only one character.

For example, if line starts with 2 tabs (4 chars wide) immediately followed by string, start column of range returned from bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor is 8 (or undefined, see below). Since getTextInBufferRange counts tab as one character, it returns string starting with eighth character which is already 6 letters inside of string I was trying to get.

Let's assume this code:

```
range = editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor(".string")
editor.getTextInBufferRange(range)
```

and this input:

```
\t\t"my string", some other text
```

If cursor is placed before "r", bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor returns undefined. That is because editor.getCursorBufferPosition (used internally by bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor) counts tab as one character and therefore it returns column < 8, which as far as bufferRangeForScopeAtPosition (also used internally by bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor) is concerned is not within any string.

If cursor is placed after "r", it returns "ring", some".

When you look at tokenizedLines in TokenizedBuffer for that line, you see that tags start [4,4,...] (4 may be replaced by actual tab width) and as far as I can currently tell this seems to be the problem. I assume that either tokenizer should not count tabs as multiple characters or bufferRangeForScopeAtPosition should not take tags as buffer column numbers.

data.title: Binary packages for 1.2.1 release are REALLY missing - with screenshot
data.body:
Hello,
I'm re-opening a ticket since #9645 was closed before I could answer.
I don't know what happened, but I can confirm there're no downloadable packages for 1.2.1. I DID wait a few days before opening the ticket because I had already noticed that the release files are attached AFTER the release is created.

![screenshot from 2015-11-17 11 28 27](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/230827/11208976/8ec1bb3e-8d1e-11e5-885f-0b6cec5681c3.png)

I don't know what you see there in the #9645 screenshot, but maybe the "draft" indication means something like "people working for GitHub/Atom can access this release, but others don't"? Have you tried accessing the releases page from an incognito window?

data.title: Enable clipboard actions in Settings screen
data.body:
It's quite inconvenient that you can't copy text in the Settings page. Quite often I have to copy config values, having to go to the project's GitHub page. Is there a workaround for this? Or any particular reason why it's restricted?

![screenshot 2015-11-17 10 01 45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1636476/11208356/90b106ea-8d12-11e5-8e7d-fecef673fd4c.png)

data.title: Binary packages for 1.2.1 release are missing
data.body:
Hello, 
1.2.1 was tagged some days ago in https://github.com/atom/atom/releases , but it seems that's just the source that's available. Will the packages be uploaded, or it was a wrong tagging?

data.title: atom not launching/application.json
"Open with Atom" removes added project folders
data.body:
I find the behaviour of right click -> Open with Atom to be non-intuitive on Windows. 

If I have any added project folders they are successfully restored every time I fire up Atom. However, when I choose to open a single file or a directory using the right click menu, all added project folders and open file tabs are removed. Next time Atom is reopened it will remember only the latest opened folder/file.

Is this by design? I believe **adding** a folder/file would be much more intuitive. Especially when you work in multiple projects in parallel.

Atom 1.1.0 on Windows 7.

data.title: Provide a method to get structured stacktrace from error.
data.body:
Atom provided a way to get raw stacktrace in [error.getRawStack](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/6e8184658090b223e9eadcdef4bd39479a30e004/src/compile-cache.js#L171) and tries to prevent further modification of [Error.prepareStackTrace](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/6e8184658090b223e9eadcdef4bd39479a30e004/src/compile-cache.js#L165). 

However, this doesn't work  if we run following:

```
const error = new Error();
error.stack;
error.getRawStack();
> "Error
    at <anonymous>:2:15
    at Object.InjectedScript._evaluateOn (<anonymous>:904:140)
    at Object.InjectedScript._evaluateAndWrap (<anonymous>:837:34)
    at Object.InjectedScript.evaluate (<anonymous>:693:21)"
```

Whereas Nuclide need this structured stack information to categorize/track errors by [customizing Error.prepareStackTrace](https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/master/pkg/nuclide/logging/lib/stacktrace.js#L30), which had caused problems describe [here](https://github.com/atom/grim/commit/8807010397e64f499b6815090d7b575aaf4a27c3#diff-dd248f5f751e9429ed611987b50f19b6R48), and https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/issues/246 .

For now, I could manually set `Error.prototype.getRawStack = null;` in our customization so that atom/grim will fallback to it's another implementation of [getRawStack](https://github.com/atom/grim/blob/master/src/grim.coffee#L80). 
But we need to fix the bug of error.getRawStack() so that Nuclide don't need to customize the stacktraces.

cc @nathansobo  @bolinfest
